FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of February&nbsp;27, 2008, 16,416,789 shares of the registrant&#146;s Common Stock were outstanding, of which 4,960,847 were held by non-affiliates of the registrant. The aggregate market value of the
registrant&#146;s Common Stock held by non-affiliates, computed by reference to the closing price of the Common Stock on the American Stock Exchange as of the last business day of the registrant&#146;s most recently completed second fiscal quarter
was $99.2 million. The exclusion of shares owned by any person from such amount shall not be deemed an admission by the registrant that such person is an affiliate of the registrant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>CERTAIN DEFINITIONS AND PRESENTATION OF GENERAL INFORMATION </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In this annual report, unless indicated otherwise in this report or the context requires otherwise, the following definitions shall apply: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Common Stock</I>. The common stock of Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp., par value $0.001. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Company</I>. Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp., together with its consolidated subsidiaries. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>DKK</I>. The Danish kroner, which is the lawful currency of Denmark. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>E.U</I>. The European Union. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Euro, &#128; or EUR.</I> The euro, which is the lawful currency of the
participating member states of the E.U. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Euroweb</I>. Euroweb Hungary and Euroweb Romania, collectively. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Euroweb Hungary</I>. Euroweb Internet Szolg&aacute;ltat&oacute; ZRt., a Hungarian company, which was an indirect subsidiary of HTCC until it merged
into Invitel effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Euroweb Romania</I>. Euroweb Romania S.A., a Romanian company, which is an indirect
subsidiary of HTCC. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>FASB</I>. The Financial Accounting Standards Board. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Foreign Subsidiaries</I>. The Memorex subsidiaries and the Company&#146;s indirect subsidiaries which are incorporated outside of Hungary, Austria, The
Netherlands and the Netherlands Antilles (other than Euroweb Romania). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>forint or HUF.</I> The Hungarian forint, which is the lawful
currency of the Republic of Hungary. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>historical concession area</I>. Each of the 54 geographically defined concessions areas for local
public fixed line voice telephony service areas in Hungary which, prior to 2002, were served by local telephone operators with exclusive rights and responsibilities for providing local fixed line telecommunications services. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Holdco I</I>. HTCC Holdco I B.V., a company incorporated in the Netherlands, which is a direct subsidiary of HTCC. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Holdco II</I>. HTCC Holdco II B.V., a company incorporated in the Netherlands, which is an indirect subsidiary of HTCC. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>HTCC</I>. Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp., a Delaware company and the parent company. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>HTCC Subsidiaries</I>. All of the subsidiary companies directly or indirectly owned by HTCC. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Hungarotel</I>. Hungarotel T&aacute;vk&ouml;zl&eacute;si Zrt., a Hungarian company, which was an indirect subsidiary of HTCC until it merged into
Invitel effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Hungarotel historical concession areas</I>. The areas in which Hungarotel operated five
telecommunications concessions granted by the Hungarian government on an exclusive basis until 2002. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Invitel</I>. Invitel
T&aacute;vk&ouml;zl&eacute;si Zrt., a Hungarian company, which is an indirect subsidiary of HTCC. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-2- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Invitel Acquisition</I>. The acquisition by the Company of Matel Holdings and its direct and indirect
subsidiaries, including its principal operating subsidiaries Invitel and Euroweb, which acquisition was completed on April&nbsp;27, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Invitel historical concession areas</I>. The areas in which Invitel operated nine telecommunications concessions granted by the Hungarian government on an exclusive basis until 2002. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Invitel Technocom</I>. Invitel Technocom Kft, a Hungarian company, which is an indirect subsidiary of HTCC. PanTel Technocom Kft. was renamed Invitel
Technocom Kft. effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Invitel Telecom</I>. Invitel Telecom Kft., a Hungarian company, which is an indirect
subsidiary of HTCC. Tele2 Magyarorsz&aacute;g Kft. was renamed Invitel Telecom Kft. effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Matel</I>. Magyar
Telecom B.V., a company incorporated in The Netherlands, which is an indirect subsidiary of HTCC. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Matel Holdings</I>. Matel Holdings
N.V., a company incorporated in The Netherlands Antilles, which is an indirect subsidiary of HTCC . </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Memorex</I>. Memorex Telex
Communications AG, an Austrian company, together with its consolidated subsidiaries. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Memorex Acquisition</I>. The acquisition by the
Company of 95.7% of the outstanding equity of Memorex, which acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of the first quarter 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Memorex Subsidiaries</I>. The consolidated subsidiaries of Memorex. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>NHH</I>. The Hungarian National Communications
Authority. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>our historical concession areas or the Company&#146;s historical concession areas</I>. The Hungarotel historical concession
areas and the Invitel historical concession areas combined. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>PanTel</I>. PanTel T&aacute;vk&ouml;zl&eacute;si Kft., a Hungarian company,
which was an indirect subsidiary of HTCC until it merged into Invitel effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>PanTel Technocom</I>. PanTel
Technocom Kft, a Hungarian company, which is an indirect <I>subsidiary</I> of HTCC. PanTel Technocom Kft. was renamed Invitel Technocom Kft. effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Registrant</I>. Refers to Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp. (HTCC), the parent company which is registered with the United States Securities and
Exchange Commission. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Report</I>. This annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>RIO</I>. Reference Interconnect Offer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>RUO</I>. Reference Unbundling Offer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>SEC</I>. The United States Securities and Exchange Commission. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>SMP</I>. Significant Market Power. A telecommunications services provider, which has been designated with significant market power following a market
analysis by the Hungarian regulatory authorities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-3- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>T-Com</I>. The brand name under which Magyar Telekom Plc. operates its fixed line telecommunications
business in Hungary. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>TDC</I>. TDC A/S, a Danish company (formerly known as Tele Danmark A/S), together with its affiliates. TDC is our
majority stockholder and owns approximately 64% of our outstanding Common Stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Tele2 Hungary</I>. Tele2 Magyarorsz&aacute;g Kft., a
Hungarian company, which is an indirect subsidiary of HTCC. Tele2 Magyarorsz&aacute;g Kft. was renamed Invitel Telecom Kft. effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Tele2 Hungary Acquisition</I>. The acquisition by the Company of Tele2 Hungary, which acquisition was completed on October&nbsp;18, 2007. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>U.S. dollar, USD or $</I>. The U.S. dollar, which is the lawful currency of the United States of America. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>V-holding</I>. V-holding Tan&aacute;csad&oacute; Zrt., a Hungarian company, which was an indirect subsidiary of HTCC until it merged into Invitel
effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>we, us and our</I>. Refers to the Company. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, we have included a glossary of certain technical terms used in this Report under the heading <I>&#147;Glossary of Terms</I>&#148;.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-4- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Glossary of Terms </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our industry uses many terms and acronyms that may not be familiar to you. To assist you in reading this Report, we have provided below definitions of some of these terms. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Access or Telephone Lines</I>. Telephone lines reaching from the customer&#146;s premises to a connection with the telephone service provider&#146;s
network. When we refer to our access lines or telephone lines, we include our customers with either a wired or fixed wireless connection to our network. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Access Network</I>. The part of the telecommunications network which connects the end users to the backbone. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Average Revenue Per User (ARPU)</I>. The average revenue per user. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM)</I>. An international
high-speed, high-volume, packet-switching protocol which supplies bandwidth on demand and divides any signal (voice, data or video) into efficient, manageable packets for ultra-fast switching. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Backbone</I>. A centralized high-speed network that interconnects smaller, independent networks. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Bitstream Access</I>. The provision of broadband access on local loops using DSL technology. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Bandwidth</I>. The number of bits of information which can move through a communications medium in a given amount of time (normally measured in bits
per second). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Broadband</I>. High speed access to the Internet. Telecommunication in which a wide band of frequencies is available to
transmit information. Because a wide band of frequencies is available, information can be multiplexed and sent on many different frequencies or channels within the band concurrently, allowing more information to be transmitted in a given amount of
time. Various definers have assigned a minimum data rate to qualify as broadband. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cable Modem</I>. A device that enables a PC to
connect to the cable TV network and receive data at a high speed. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Carrier Pre-Selection (CPS)</I>. The ability to select the
telecommunications services provider for certain calls on a pre-set basis so that the selected telecommunications services provider is the default telecommunications services provider on such calls without having to dial a prefix. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Carrier Selection (CS)</I>. The ability to select the telecommunications services provider for certain calls on a call-by-call basis, whereby a
telecommunications services provider different from the default telecommunications services provider may be selected by the customer by dialing a prefix when making certain calls. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Central Office (CO)</I>. The site with the local telecommunications services provider&#146;s equipment that routes calls to and from customers. It
also connects customers to Internet Service Providers and long distance carriers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Churn</I>. A measure of customers who stop purchasing
our services as manifested by the loss of either voice traffic (as measured in minutes) or lines, leading to reduced revenue. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Co-location</I>. A type of service where the customer&#146;s telecommunications equipment and/or other hardware and equipment is housed within the provider&#146;s facilities usually for the purpose of connecting the customer&#146;s
network with other networks. The co-location provider is typically responsible for power and connectivity. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-5- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Dark Fiber</I>. Unused fiber optic cable. Fiber optic cables convey information in the form of light
pulses so that &#147;dark&#148; fiber means that no light pulses are being sent over the fiber optic cable. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Dense Wavelength Division
Multiplexing (DWDM)</I>. A technology which multiplexes multiple optical carrier signals on a single optical fiber by using different wavelengths (colors) of laser light to carry different signals. This allows for a multiplication in capacity, in
addition to making it possible to perform bi-directional communications over one strand of fiber. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Digital. </I>A method of storing,
processing and transmitting information through the use of distinct electronic or optical pulses that represent the binary digits 0 and 1. Digital transmission and switching technologies employ a sequence of these pulses to represent information as
opposed to the continuously variable analog signal. The precise digital numbers minimize distortion (such as graininess or snow in the case of video transmission, or static or other background distortion in the case of audio transmission).
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Digital Enhanced Cordless Telecommunications (DECT</I>)<I>. A wireless standard based on time division multiple access technology used
for wireless local loop systems.</I> </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Digital Subscriber Line (DSL)</I>. An access technology that allows voice and high-speed data to
be sent simultaneously over local exchange service copper facilities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ethernet</I>. A local area network architecture. It is the most
common type of connection computers use in a local area network. An Ethernet port looks like a regular phone jack, but is slightly wider. This port can be used to connect a computer to another computer, a local network, or an external DSL or cable
modem. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Extranet</I>. An intranet that is partially accessible to authorized outsiders. It provides limited external access to certain
resources on an organization&#146;s corporate network. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Fiber Optic Cable</I>. A type of cable made from hair-thin glass (rather than
copper) through which information travels as light. Fiber optic cables have a much greater bandwidth capacity than metal cables. Fiber optic cables form the basis for telecommunication providers&#146; backbone networks in transmitting information
long distances. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Fixed Lines/Fixed Telephone Lines</I>. Refers to both wireline and fixed wireless telephone access lines. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Fixed Wireless</I>. The operation of wireless devices (such as a telephone) in fixed locations such as homes and offices. The geographic range of
the mobility is limited to a small area. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Frame Relay (FR)</I>. An industry-standard switched data link layer protocol, typically used
for high speed data transmission through leased lines. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>GSM</I>. Global system for mobile communications. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Incumbent</I>. The dominant operator which was licensed to enter the market and establish a proprietary network under the protection of a regulatory
monopoly. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Incumbent Local Telephone Operator (ILTO)</I>. A traditional fixed line telecommunications services provider that, until
2002, had the exclusive right and responsibility for providing local telecommunications services in certain local service areas within Hungary. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN)</I>. An international telecommunications standard which enables high speed simultaneous transmission of voice and/or data over an existing public network. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-6- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Internet</I>. A public network based on a common communication protocol which supports communication
through the world wide web. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Internet Protocol (IP)</I>. A protocol for transferring information across the Internet in packets of data.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Internet Service Provider (ISP)</I>. A business that provides Internet access to customers. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>ISDN2</I>. ISDN access with two channels designed primarily for residential use. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>ISDN30</I>. ISDN access with 30 channels designed primarily for business use. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Last Mile</I>. The telecommunications technology that connects the customer&#146;s premises directly to the network of the telecommunications
provider, traditionally a wired connection through a twisted pair copper wire telephone cable (in the case of the telecommunications provider) or a coaxial cable (in the case of a cable television operator) but it can also be a fixed wireless
connection. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Leased Line</I>. A permanent (always on for continual transmission), dedicated fiber optic or telephone line connection
between two points, which is typically leased by business customers enabling the connection of two geographically distant points. They are used to transmit voice, data or video between the sites. Also known as Private Lines and Dedicated Lines.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Local Area Network (LAN)</I>. A network located in a single location such as a floor, department or building. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Local Loop</I>. The telephone line that runs from the local telephone company&#146;s equipment to the end user&#146;s premise. The local loop can be
made up of fiber, copper or wireless media. It usually refers to the wired connection from a telephone company&#146;s central office in a local area to its customer&#146;s premises. It is also known as the subscriber loop, local line, access line,
telephone line, fixed line or fixed telephone line. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Local Loop Unbundling (LLU)</I>. The process of making the local loop available to
the local loop owner&#146;s competitors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>LRIC</I>. A cost accounting methodology focusing on long-run incremental costs. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Managed Leased Line</I>. A leased line monitored, managed and controlled by a network management system offering an increased level of flexibility,
reliability and security. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Metropolitan Area Network (MAN)</I>. A network that covers a metropolitan area such as a portion of a city.
The area is larger than that covered by a local area network but smaller than the area covered by a wide area network. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>MLLN</I>. A
managed leased line network. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mobile</I>. Generally refers to wireless or cellular telecommunications with limited geographical
constraints. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Multiplexing</I>. The combination of multiple analog or digital signals for transmission over a single line. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS)</I>. A widely supported method of speeding up data communications over combined IP/ATM networks. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-7- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Network</I>. An arrangement of data devices that can communicate with each other such as the telephone
network over which telephones and modems communicate with each other. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>number portability</I>. The ability of a customer to transfer
from one telecom operator to another and retain the original telephone number. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Private Automatic Branch Exchange (PABX)</I>. A digital
or analog telephone switchboard located within the customer&#146;s premises and used to connect private and public telephone networks. It routes calls both within an organization and from the outside world to/from people within the organization.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Point of Presence (POP)</I>. The physical location where the line from a long distance carrier or the server of an Internet Service
Provider connects to the line of the local telecommunications services provider (usually at the local telephone company&#146;s central office). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Point-to-Multipoint (PMP)</I>. Refers to the use of microwave technology to link the telecommunications services provider&#146;s point-of-presence with a number of remote customer locations. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Point-to-Point (PP)</I>. Refers to the use of microwave technology to link the telecommunications services provider&#146;s point-of-presence directly
with one single customer location. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN)</I>. A traditional landline network for voice telephony.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>SME</I>. Refers to small and medium-sized enterprises. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>SoHo</I>. Refers to small office/home office. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SDH).</I> The
international standard for synchronous data transmission over fiber optic cables. The North American equivalent of SDH in SONET. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Tier 1
Provider</I>. A Tier 1 provider is a network operator of an IP network which connects to the entire Internet solely via Settlement Free Interconnection, commonly known as &#147;peering&#148;. Tier 1 providers have service level agreements which
include 99.9% uptime guarantees, impressive security, continuous and clean power and protection from fire, earthquakes and other disasters. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Transit Services</I>. An interconnection service whereby a carrier provides transportation services for information (voice, data and video) by linking two networks that are not directly interconnected. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Universal Mobile Telecommunications System (UMTS)</I>. A third generation (3G)&nbsp;wireless system designed to provide a wide range of voice, high
speed data and multimedia services. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Unbundling</I>. The granting of unbundled access to the local loop so that the third party
operators requesting access to the local loop are not required to purchase interconnection services from the incumbent operator; also referred to as &#147;local loop unbundling&#148;. See the definition of &#147;Unbundled Network Elements&#148;
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Unbundled Network Elements (UNEs).</I> The discrete elements of a telecommunications services provider&#146;s network that are sold or
leased to competing telecommunications services providers, which elements may be combined to enable that competitor to provide retail telecommunications services. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN)</I>. A network architecture which allows geographically distributed users to communicate as if they were on a single physical local area network. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-8- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Virtual Private Network (VPN)</I>. A private network (often an Intranet) that operates securely within
a public network (such as the Internet) by means of encrypting transmissions. It provides the functions and features of a private network without the need for dedicated private lines (leased lines) between an end-user organization&#146;s different
sites. Each site of the end-user organization is connected to the network provider&#146;s network rather than directly to the end-user&#146;s other sites. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP)</I>. The transmission of voice using Internet-based technology over a broadband connection rather than a traditional wire and switch-based telephone network. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Wide Area Network (WAN)</I>. A geographically dispersed network that is housed in more than one location. Its area is larger than that covered by a
metropolitan area network. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Wireless Local Loop</I>. A wireless connection between the customer&#146;s premises and the telephone
company&#146;s central office. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Wholesale naked DSL.</I> The provision of DSL services on a stand-alone basis without fixed line voice
services. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, we have included a list of certain other defined terms used in this Report under the heading <I>&#147;Certain
Definitions and Presentation of General Information</I>&#148;. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-9- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In this Report certain amounts stated in euros, forints and kroner have also been stated in U.S. dollars solely for the informational purposes of the
reader, and should not be construed as a representation that such euro, forint or krone amounts actually represent such U.S. dollar amounts or could be, or could have been, converted into U.S. dollars at the rate indicated or at any other rate.
Unless otherwise stated or the context otherwise requires, such amounts have been stated at December&nbsp;31, 2007 exchange rates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Forint per Euro </B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table sets out, for the periods and dates indicated, the period-end, average, high and low official rates set by the National
Bank of Hungary for forint per &#128;1.00. We make no representation that the forint amounts referred to in this Report could have been or could be converted into any currency at any particular rate or at all. As of February 28, 2008, the rate was
258.54. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>CAUTIONARY STATEMENTS CONCERNING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This Annual Report on Form 10-K contains forward-looking statements. Statements that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements made
pursuant to the Safe Harbor Provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on our estimates and assumptions and are subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ
materially from those expressed or implied in the statements. Words such as &#147;believes,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;expects&#148;, &#147;intends&#148; and similar expressions are intended to identify
forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements (including oral representations) are only predictions or statements of current plans, which we review continuously. For all forward-looking statements, we claim the protection of the safe harbor
for forward-looking statements contained in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following important factors, along
with those factors discussed elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K and in our other reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, could affect future results and could cause those results to differ materially from those expressed
in the forward-looking statements: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-13- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>PART I </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;1. Business. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>COMPANY OVERVIEW </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp. (&#147;HTCC&#148; or the &#147;Registrant&#148;) was incorporated in Delaware in 1992 as a holding company to acquire
concessions from the government of the Republic of Hungary to own and operate local fixed line telecommunications networks in Hungary as Hungary privatized its telecommunications industry. Today, we are the second largest fixed line
telecommunications services provider in Hungary and the incumbent provider of fixed line telecommunications services to residential and business customers in our 14 historical concession areas, where we have a dominant market share. We are also the
number one alternative fixed line operator outside our historical concession areas. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our 14 historical concession areas are geographically
clustered and cover an estimated 2.1&nbsp;million people, representing approximately 21% of Hungary&#146;s population. Outside our historical concession areas, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to grow our revenue and market share
using our owned state-of-the-art backbone network, our experienced sales force and our comprehensive portfolio of services. Our extensive national fiber network (comprising approximately 10,000 route km of fiber) provides us with nationwide reach,
allowing business customers to be connected directly to our network to access voice, data and Internet services outside our historical concession areas. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition to our Hungarian business, we are a provider of wholesale data and capacity services as well as voice transit services throughout Central and Eastern Europe, where we provide services in 14 countries in
the region. Our clients include the incumbent telecommunications services providers in these countries as well as alternative fixed line telecommunications services providers, mobile operators, cable television operators and Internet Service
Providers. We also provide services to telecommunication services providers from Western Europe and the United States, enabling them to meet the regional demands of their corporate clients. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We operate in the following four markets: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mass Market Voice. </I>We provide a full range of basic and value-added voice-related services to our residential and small office and home office
(&#147;SoHo&#148;) customers both inside and outside our historical concession areas. These services include local, national and international calling, voicemail, fax, ISDN and directory assistance services. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mass Market Internet. </I>We provide DSL broadband and dial-up Internet services to our Mass Market customers nationwide. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Business. </I>We provide fixed line voice, data and Internet services to business (comprised of small and medium-sized enterprises (&#147;SMEs&#148;) and larger
corporations), government and other institutional customers nationwide. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Wholesale. </I>We provide voice, data and network capacity services on a wholesale basis to a number of other telecommunications and Internet service providers
both within Hungary and other countries within Central and Eastern Europe. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have a diversified revenue and cash flow
base, making us less susceptible to market pressures in any particular market. For the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, we derived approximately 28% of our revenue from Mass Market Voice, 9% from Mass Market Internet, 33% from Business and
30% from </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-14- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Wholesale. See Note 19 in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional financial information on our market segments and our geographical
operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we had approximately 405,000 telephone lines connected to our networks within our 14 historical
concession areas serving Mass Market customers and we had approximately 754,000 Mass Market Voice customers outside our historical concession areas primarily using either Carrier Pre-Selection (&#147;CPS&#148;) or Carrier Selection (&#147;CS&#148;)
based voice services with a limited number of customers connecting through Local Loop Unbundling (&#147;LLU&#148;). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of
December&nbsp;31, 2007, we had approximately 122,000 Mass Market broadband DSL customers, of which approximately 97,000 were connected directly to our networks within our historical concession areas and 25,000 were outside our historical concession
areas and serviced principally by our purchasing wholesale DSL services from the incumbent local telephone operator (primarily T-Com. &#147;T-Com&#148; is the brand name under which Magyar Telekom Plc. operates its fixed line telecommunications
business in Hungary). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B></B>As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, in the Business market we had approximately 47,000 voice telephone lines within
our historical concessions areas and approximately 71,000 voice telephone lines outside our historical concession areas (including approximately 13,000 serviced through CPS and a limited number of customers connected through LLU). As of
December&nbsp;31, 2007, we had approximately 16,000 DSL connections and approximately 12,000 leased lines. <B> </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the Wholesale
market, we had over 300 customers as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, which customers include telecommunication services providers from Western Europe and the United States, incumbent telecommunications services providers, alternative fixed line
telecommunications services providers, mobile operators, cable television operators, Internet Service Providers, and governments. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our
current business is a result of the recent combination of Invitel with our existing business. On April&nbsp;27, 2007, we acquired Invitel for a total consideration, including the assumption of net indebtedness on closing, of &#128;470&nbsp;million
(approximately $639 million at closing). Invitel was the second largest fixed line telecommunications services provider in Hungary and the incumbent provider of fixed line telecommunications services in nine historical concession areas while we were
the third largest fixed line telecommunications services provider in Hungary and the incumbent provider of fixed line telecommunications services in five historical concession areas. We are now better able to compete against T-Com, the former
national monopoly, which is the largest fixed line telecommunications services provider in Hungary. We believe that we will realize approximately &#128;17&nbsp;million (approximately $25.7 million at current exchange rates) in annualized operating
expense synergies as a result of the Invitel Acquisition by the end of 2008. This exceeds our original estimate of &#128;14&nbsp;million (approximately $21.1 million at current exchange rates) that we estimated when we announced that we had agreed
to purchase Invitel in January 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We were providing and marketing services in Hungary through our Hungarian subsidiaries Hungarotel,
PanTel and PanTel Technocom and internationally through PanTel, while Invitel was providing and marketing services in Hungary through Invitel and Euroweb Hungary and internationally through Invitel. Invitel was also providing and marketing Internet
and data services to business customers in Romania through its Romanian subsidiary, Euroweb Romania. Following the Invitel Acquisition, we decided to market all of our products and services under a single unified brand name &#150; Invitel (except in
Romania, where we maintain the Euroweb brand). At the end of 2007, we merged some of our operating subsidiaries (including Hungarotel, Euroweb Hungary and PanTel) into Invitel in order to realize additional synergies. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;18, 2007 we purchased the Hungarian business of Tele2, the Swedish-based alternative telecom operator by purchasing the entire equity
interests in Tele2&#146;s Hungarian subsidiary </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">-15- </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(&#147;Tele2 Hungary&#148;) for &#128;4&nbsp;million in cash (approximately $5.7 million at closing). Tele2 Hungary (renamed Invitel Telecom Kft.) provides
Carrier Selection and Carrier Pre-Selection fixed line telecommunications services to the Mass Market as a reseller using the network facilities of other operators pursuant to regulated resale agreements. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We had $385 million in total revenue in 2007. Including Invitel&#146;s and Tele2 Hungary&#146;s full year 2007 revenue (including pre-closing revenue),
we had $505 million in pro-forma total revenue in 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On December&nbsp;20, 2007, we entered into an agreement to purchase 95.7% of the
outstanding equity in Austrian-based Memorex. The purchase price for Memorex is &#128;30.3&nbsp;million (approximately $45.8 million at current exchange rates) for the 95.7% equity interest plus the assumption of Memorex&#146;s debt. We intend to
refinance a significant portion of Memorex&#146;s debt at closing. We intend to fund the Memorex Acquisition and the refinancing of the assumed Memorex debt with a subordinated bridge loan facility, which we expect to replace in due course with
longer term financing. We also intend to buy out the remaining minority shareholders in Memorex. We expect the Memorex Acquisition to be completed by the end of the first quarter 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Memorex is one of the leading alternative telecommunications providers in the Central and Eastern European region. Memorex provides wholesale data and
capacity services to leading global telecommunications providers and Internet companies between 14 countries in the region including Austria, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Italy, Romania, Slovakia, Turkey, and Ukraine. Memorex operates over 12,500
route km of fiber optic cable in the region which enables it to provide high quality wholesale services to large international carriers. Memorex has invested approximately &#128;54&nbsp;million (approximately $81.5 million at current exchange rates)
in its network over the last two years. The Memorex Acquisition will further develop our position in the Wholesale market in the region. Following the acquisition of Memorex, we will be the leading provider of wholesale data and capacity services in
the Central and Eastern European market. In addition, we expect to benefit from cost synergies with expected annual operating cost savings of &#128;3&nbsp;million (approximately $4.5 million at current exchange rates) and capital expenditure
synergies of approximately &#128;2.4&nbsp;million (approximately $3.6 million at current exchange rates) during the first two years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our
goal is to provide customers with good value telecommunications services coupled with exceptional service and to be a cost efficient telecommunications services provider. Our primary risk is our ability to retain existing customers and attract new
customers in a competitive market. Our success depends upon our operating and marketing strategies, as well as market demand for our telecommunications services within Hungary and the Central and Eastern Europe region. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our directors and officers own approximately 6% of our outstanding Common Stock. TDC A/S, a Danish company formerly known as Tele Danmark A/S (together
with its affiliates, &#147;TDC&#148;), owns approximately 64% of our outstanding Common Stock. The remaining approximately 30% of our outstanding Common Stock is held in the public markets. Our Common Stock is traded on the American Stock Exchange
under the symbol &#147;HTC.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our principal office in Hungary is located at Puskas Tivadar u. 8-10 u. 8&#150;10, H-2040 Buda&ouml;rs;
telephone (361)&nbsp;801-1500. Our United States office is located at 1201 Third Avenue, Suite 3400, Seattle, Washington 98101-3034; telephone (206)&nbsp;654-0204. Our web site address is http://www.htcc.hu and it contains a link to our filings with
the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the &#147;SEC&#148;). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On the following pages, you will find: (i)&nbsp;a map showing
Hungary&#146;s location within Europe; (ii)&nbsp;a diagram showing our historical concessions areas in Hungary, along with our Hungarian telecommunications backbone network; (iii)&nbsp;a diagram showing our international wholesale network; and
(iv)&nbsp;a diagram showing our expected corporate structure following the Memorex Acquisition. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Organizational Structure </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"
